str2: A prolonged form of the feminine of moichos; an adulteress.

parse: Verb - Perfect Indicative Active - 2nd Person Plural
str2: To know, remember, appreciate.
Neuter of hostis as conjunction; demonstrative, that; causative, because.
Friendship, affection, fondness, love. From philos; fondness.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Probably from the base of komizo; orderly arrangement, i.e. Decoration; by implication, the world (morally).

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Active - 3rd Person Singular
str2: I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.
Enmity, hostility, alienation. Feminine of echthros; hostility; by implication, a reason for opposition.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
A deity, especially the supreme Divinity; figuratively, a magistrate; by Hebraism, very.
Therefore, then. Apparently a primary word; certainly, or accordingly.

parse: Personal / Relative Pronoun - Nominative Masculine Singular
str2: Who, which, what, that.

parse: Verb - Aorist Subjunctive Passive - 3rd Person Singular
str2: To will, intend, desire, wish. Middle voice of a primary verb; to 'will, ' i.e. be willing.
I am, exist. The first person singular present indicative; a prolonged form of a primary and defective verb; I exist.
Friendly; subst: a friend, an associate. Properly, dear, i.e. A friend; actively, fond, i.e. Friendly.
The, the definite article. Including the feminine he, and the neuter to in all their inflections; the definite article; the.
Probably from the base of komizo; orderly arrangement, i.e. Decoration; by implication, the world (morally).

parse: Verb - Present Indicative Middle or Passive - 3rd Person Singular
str2: From kata and histemi; to place down, i.e. to designate, constitute, convoy.
Hated, hostile; subst: an enemy. From a primary echtho; hateful; usually as a noun, an adversary.
A deity, especially the supreme Divinity; figuratively, a magistrate; by Hebraism, very.
